newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS- Pakistan, Malaysians in market.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS- Pakistan, Malaysians in market.

text.p: Pakistan's much-anticipated floating rate note issue was one of the highlights of a busy Asian debt market on Tuesday.
As expected, the issue size was increased from the US$100 million that was the minimum amount to be launched.
The US$300 million in notes have a three-year maturity and were priced to yield 395 basis points over comparable U.S. Treasuries. ANZ Investment Bank was lead manager.
That spread was a bit tighter than the pre-launch price talk of around 400 basis points.
Stephen Finch, director of new issues at ANZ Investment Bank in London, said the issue featured a wide geographical distribution.
"We sold about 10-15 percent in Asia, about the same amount to offshore funds in the U.S. and the rest was about evenly split between Europe and the Middle East," said Finch.
Debt funds were the biggest investors, but private investors and Asian regional banks also participated, he said.
A group for the issue has been formed and the syndicate will break in the London afternoon.
The issue has been rated B2 by Moody's Investors Service.
Malaysian companies also featured in an active Asian debt market on Tuesday.
Malaysian Airline set a 30 billion yen bond that was quickly increased to 40 billion yen. The five-year issue was priced at par and pays a semi-annual coupon of 2.55 percent.
Daiwa Securities (HK) was lead manager.
The issue followed Monday's yen floating rate note issue for Malaysian Air, a five-year FRN that pays a margin of 25 basis points over the London Interbank Offered Rate.
Fees are 15 basis points for the FRN, which was lead managed by Daiwa and Sanwa International Finance.
Both the bond and the FRN can be put if the Minister of Finance ceases to hold preference shares in the borrower.
Chase Manhattan Asia brought a US$50 million FRN for Mycom Capital. The three-year deal pays 175 basis points over LIBOR and offers 20 basis points in fees to the top tier.
Another Malaysian company, Mancon, has a US$100 million FRN in the market via lead manager Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
Malaysian credits have become increasingly popular as investors seek out investment-grade alternatives among Asian issuers now that South Korean and Thai issuers have turned quiet.
In the loan markets, Hong Kong's CITIC Pacific has mandated five banks to arrange a HK$8 billion loan facility.
Banque Nationale de Paris Hong Kong branch, Chase Manhattan Asia, HSBC Investment Bank Asia, Hang Seng Bank and J.P. Morgan Securities Asia are the coordinating arrangers and underwriters.
Proceeds of the loan will be used for refinancing of existing debts and for general corporate purposes, the arrangers said in a statement.
Earlier today, bankers said CITIC Pacific was planning to raise HK$8.0 billion to help fund its investment in China Light and Power Co.

They said the loan would be used for working capital and to repay a short-term HK$12.5 billion bridging loan signed in February to help fund the company's HK$16.25 billion acquisition of 20 percent of CLP.
The HK$12.5 billion bridging loan had a tenor of less than one year and was not syndicated.
On May 9, CITIC Pacific said it had agreed to sell a 7.74 percent stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd for HK$11.4 billion.
